item.title: Borderlands 3: pure chaos, solo fun
item.description:
Since picking up Borderlands 3, I’ve spent most evenings blowing things up as Moze, the Gunner. She’s perfect when you just want to log in, fire up Iron Bear, and let the explosions do the talking.

Why Moze?

I picked her for the mech — no deep reason. But turns out she’s super versatile:

  • Explosives-heavy builds
  • Infinite ammo
  • Tanky Iron Bear uptime

I went full explosives. Torgue shotguns, sticky bombs, MIRV grenades, Iron Bear rocket pods. Big booms, fast clears.

Playing Solo Just Works

Yeah, co-op is fun. But solo lets me:

  • Explore at my own pace
  • Retry bosses without pressure
  • Enjoy the chaos on my terms

Sometimes I just walk through zones, listen to ambient sounds — then drop Iron Bear and wipe everything.

My Go-To Build (Explosive Moze)

Weapons

  • Torgue shotguns
  • COV rifles for sustained fire
  • Anointment: +100% splash while Iron Bear active

Grenades

  • MIRV + elemental effects

Iron Bear

  • Vanquisher Rocket Pods x2
  • Auto Bear for extra DPS and distraction

Key Skills (Demolition Woman)

  • Fire in the Skag Den
  • Pull the Holy Pin
  • Short Fuse

Every shot and grenade is a chance for chain explosions.

item.title: Gris & Neva: beautiful art!!
item.description:
Gris: No Enemies, No Words, Still Works

Gris is a platformer without combat.
You move, jump, unlock a few abilities, and that’s it.

But the way the environment shifts — from black and white to color, from stillness to motion — carries the whole experience.
No tutorials, no dialogue. Just visual storytelling done right.

The music is subtle but effective. It feels more like an interactive short film than a “game,” and that’s not a bad thing.

If you want something short, quiet, and artistically sharp, Gris is solid.

Neva: Same Style, Different Mood

Neva is from the same studio, but it leans more into nature, movement, and mood swings.
You explore a forest with a companion creature, solve environmental puzzles, and figure things out as you go — no hand-holding.

The animation is smooth, the creature design is great, and the environments shift between beautiful and unsettling.

item.title: It Takes Two — A Game We Played Together
item.description:
I played It Takes Two with ZGY.
It’s one of the most memorable co-op games we’ve ever played — full of creativity, fun, and emotions.

From the very beginning, when we figured out how to move those little toy figures, to all the crazy puzzle mechanics that forced us to communicate and cooperate, we laughed, struggled, and sometimes just stared at the screen wondering what to do next.

The game had some painful parts too (yes, that elephant scene — still hurts to think about it). But mostly, it was about learning to be a team.

And yes, when we reached the attic, and that letter appeared, I realized that’s exactly what I wanted to say to ZGY.
So here it is:

From Cody to May:

I miss you and long for you every minute of the day.
The only time I’m not missing you is when I’m asleep,
but even then, I’m dreaming about you.

item.title: Detroit: Become Human — A Game About Choices and Humanity
item.description:
I played Detroit: Become Human during a quiet period in life, and it left a lasting impression — not because of action or graphics (though both are good), but because of how it handles storytelling and choice-making.

Not Just a Game, But an Interactive Story

At its core, Detroit: Become Human is about choices and consequences. You play as three different androids — Connor, Kara, and Markus — each with their own storyline that eventually connects.

What makes this game special is how much control you have over the story.
Almost every decision you make — from small conversations to life-and-death moments — shapes the outcome, sometimes in unexpected ways.

I enjoyed seeing how different dialogue options could lead to completely different scenes, relationships, and endings. It’s like playing a movie, but you’re the director of every scene.

Themes of Humanity and Morality

item.title: Zelda and Me
item.description:
I first played Breath of the Wild during the pandemic lockdown.
Classes were online, everything felt repetitive, and most days blurred together.

Then came Hyrule — open, quiet, and far from reality.
I didn’t rush to beat the game. I just walked. Climbed. Cooked food. Waited out the rain.

In a time when I couldn’t go anywhere, this game gave me somewhere to be.

Come on, who actually goes to rescue the princess? Hyrule itself is the real paradise.

Playing, Not Escaping

Link doesn’t talk, but he moves forward — and that was enough.
No big speeches, no drama. Just a broken world, and someone doing what they can.

Some days, it felt like he was the only other person around.
So I kept playing — not to finish, but to stay.

Tears of the Kingdom Didn’t Hit the Same

When Tears of the Kingdom came out, I thought I’d dive back in.
But I didn’t. I played a bit, admired the new mechanics, and put it down.

item.title: Little Nightmares — A Dark Fairy Tale You Don’t Forget
item.description:
Little Nightmares: Quiet Horror That Stays With You

I played Little Nightmares a while ago, and some of its moments still linger.
It doesn’t explain much — but it doesn’t have to. You just feel it.

A Game That Says Nothing, But Means a Lot

There’s barely any dialogue. You play as Six, a small figure in a yellow raincoat, trying to escape a strange, sinking world called The Maw.

What got me was the atmosphere — eerie, quiet, and always tense.
You’re not fighting back. Just running, hiding, surviving. That sense of helplessness makes everything feel more real.

Beautiful, in a Disturbing Way

Visually, the game is like a broken fairy tale.
Distorted creatures, oversized rooms, flickering lights — nothing feels quite right, and that’s the point.

It’s not about jump scares. The fear comes from being small in a world that doesn’t care.

item.title: Crusader Kings III: Where History Meets Chaos — A Personal Journey
item.description:
If you’ve ever dreamed of being a medieval queen or king, plotting the downfall of enemies, surviving political intrigue, or marrying off relatives to secure alliances — Crusader Kings III (CK3) is the ultimate stage to live out those dreams. But for me, CK3 is not just a strategy game. It’s a sandbox for chaos, a place where history, power, and human flaws collide in ways no other game can replicate.

Why CK3?

When life gets overwhelming, some people read books, some people go hiking — I start a dynasty in CK3.

I think what makes CK3 different is that you never fully “control” your story. You might start as a powerful queen, but within two generations, your dynasty could be split by succession wars, assassinated by angry vassals, or reduced to a minor count.

And I love that.

“Life is unpredictable, and so is CK3.”

item.title: Hades — A Roguelike That Feels Personal
item.description:
I played Hades during my time exploring indie and narrative-driven games, and it quickly became one of my favorites.
Unlike many action games, Hades combines fast-paced combat with a story that actually matters.

More Than Just a Roguelike

At first, I was drawn to Hades because of its smooth action gameplay — the combat is fast, responsive, and has a lot of variety depending on the weapon and “boons” you choose.
But what really surprised me was how much story and character development there is.

Every time you die (and you die a lot — it’s a roguelike after all), the story moves forward.
You get new conversations with characters like Zagreus, Hades, Nyx, and the Olympian gods, and slowly piece together why Zagreus is trying to escape the Underworld.

Greek Mythology, but Fresh

One of the best parts of Hades is how it brings Greek mythology to life — but in a way that feels modern.
The gods are funny, flawed, and complicated, and your relationships with them evolve as you play.
Unlike some games that just “borrow” mythology as a setting, Hades really makes you feel like you are part of that world.
